Moreover, regarding **Shào Zǐ** (邵子)’s writings, his discourse on *Dàodé* (道德) and *gōnglì* (功力) elucidates the distinctions of *Huáng*, *Dì*, *Wáng*, and *Bó*—his meaning I have privately adopted.

As for observing phenomena (*guānwù* 观物), divining through *guà* (卦), *qì* (气), and *yīnlǜ* (音律), there is already the *Huángjī Jīngshì Shū* (皇极经世书) for that.

The **Teachings of the Daoist School** for later generations—**Du Dàojiān** (杜道坚) of **Cùchū** (当涂) has annotated this.

In the **Chapter of Birth** (降生章), **Lǎozǐ** (老子) says:
*"I do not know whose son I am; I precede the **Xiàngdì** (象帝)."*

According to the *Jì* (纪) and *Zhuàn* (传), **Lǎozǐ** is the **ancestor of the Great Dao** (大道之祖), and his **qi** (气) precedes **Xiàngdì** (象帝)—the **Heavenly Sovereign** (天). Thus, it is said:
*"Before Heaven I was born, born yet formless.
After Heaven I exist, existing yet without substance.
Only because I am formless and without substance,
do I have no fixed name.
Only because I have no fixed name,
do I appear and vanish without measure.
Perhaps this refers to **Hùndùnshì** (混沌氏)?"*

In Heaven, he is called:
**Xūhuáng Tiānzūn** (虚皇天尊),
**Wújí Dàodé Jūn** (无极大道君),
**Tiānhuáng Yàopò Bǎogāo** (天皇曜魄宝高上),
**Lǎozǐ Tiānhuáng Dàdì** (老子天皇大帝),
**Jiǔtiān Shànghuáng Dòngzhēn Dì** (九天上皇洞真帝),
**Yījūn** (一君),
**Tàiqīng Tiānzūn** (太清天尊),
**Tàishàng Xuányuán Lǎojūn** (太上玄元老君),
**Jīnquè Hòushèng Jūn** (金阙后圣君),
**Jiǔlǎo Xiāndū Jūn** (九老仙都君),
**Tàishàng Zhàngrén Jìnglǎo Tiānzūn** (太上丈人静老天君),
and **Zhēnyuán Jiàozhǔ Jīnquè Dìjūn** (真元教主金阙帝君).

When he descends into the world, he is called:
**Tōngxuán Tiānshī** (通玄天师),
**Pángǔ Xiānshēng** (盘古先生),
**Yǒugǔ Dà Xiānshēng** (有古大先生),
**Xuánzhōng Dà Fǎshī** (玄中大法师),
**Yùhuá Zǐ** (郁华子),
**Guǎngshòu Zǐ** (广寿子),
**Dàchéng Zǐ** (大成子),
**Guǎngchéng Zǐ** (广成子),
**Suìyìng Zǐ** (随应子),
**Chìjīng Zǐ** (赤精子),
**Lùtú Zǐ** (录图子),
**Wùchéng Zǐ** (务成子),
**Yǐnshòu Zǐ** (尹寿子),
and **Zhēnxíng Zǐ** (真行子).

Is this not the **Lǎozǐ** (老子) who is said to be the **Master of Ten Thousand Phenomena** (万象主) and the **Teacher of the Sovereign** (帝者师), whose titles vary without end?

As for the names **Xuányuán Huángdì** (玄元皇帝),
**Dàodé Xuányuán Huángdì** (大道玄元皇帝),
**Tàishàng Hùnyuán Tiānhuáng Dàdì** (太上混元天皇大帝),
**Gāoshàng Dàodé Jīnquè Xuányuán Tiānhuáng Dàdì** (高上大道金阙玄元天皇大帝),
and **Tàishàng Lǎojūn Hùnyuán Shàngdé Huángdì** (太上老君混元上德皇帝),
these are the **imperial titles conferred** (册封之号) upon him by successive dynasties.

*"Hidden in the **Tàiwú** (太无), manifesting in the **Tàichū** (太初), wandering in the **Tàixū** (太虚), giving birth to Heaven and Earth, governing gods and ghosts, and the **Sovereign of the Divine** (神帝),—since antiquity, before Heaven and Earth existed, he has ever endured. Is this not referring to **Lǎojūn** (老君)?"*

A humble **disciple of Lǎozǐ** (老子徒), I dare to cite and expand upon this.

According to the *Běn Jì* (本纪), **Lǎozǐ** (老子) was of the **Lǐ** (李) surname, given name **Ěr** (耳), courtesy name **Bóyáng** (伯阳), and posthumous title **Dān** (聃).

From **Lìyù Xiāngqǔ** (亳苦县濑), also written as **Lìxiāng Qǔrénlǐ** (厉乡曲仁里), a daughter of the **Yǐn** (尹) family conceived through the **sacred light of the sun** (日精) and gave birth to him in the **24th year of Shāng Wǔdīng** (商武丁), on the **15th day of the second month**, **Gēngchén** (庚辰).

The **Shāng** (商) dynasty took **chǒu** (丑) as the beginning of the year, and the second month began with **yín** (寅), corresponding to the **first month’s *Yuánxiāo Jié* (上元节)** in today’s reckoning.

He was born able to speak, pointing to **Lǐ** (李) as his surname, and because of his **white-haired head** (皓首), he was called **Lǎozǐ** (老子).

His **auspicious omens at birth** (祯祥) are fully recorded in the *Jì* (纪) and *Zhuàn* (传).

Now, in **Lìyù** (亳), the **Tàiqīng Palace** (太清宫), the **Jiǔlóng Jǐng** (九龙井), and the **Báilù Huì** (白鹿桧)—**sacred traces** (圣迹) remain.

The **Di Xīn** (帝辛) of the **Shāng** (商) in his twenty-first year, **Dīngmǎo** (丁卯), cleared the ground at **Qíshān** (岐山). The **West伯 of Zhōu** (周西伯) summoned and appointed him as **Guardian of the Hidden Archives** (守藏史). When **Wǔ Wáng** (武王) relocated him to **Zhùxià Shǐ** (柱下史), **Chéng Wáng** (成王) retained him in the same post. At the beginning of **Zhāo Wáng’s** (昭王) reign, he resigned and returned to **Bì** (亳).

In the twenty-sixth year, **Guǐchǒu** (癸丑), he crossed the **Hángǔ Pass** (函谷关) and, at **Zhōngnán Shān** (终南山), taught **Jiān Yǐn Xī** (关尹喜) the *Dàodé* (道德) in two scrolls within a thatched pavilion. He then departed through **Dàsàn Guān** (大散关), meeting Jiān Yǐn Xī at **Qīngyáng Sì** (青羊肆) in **Chéngdū** (成都) before journeying westward with him.

When **Mù Wáng** (穆王) returned from his western hunt to **Zhōu** (周), he was deeply moved by the **mysterious Dao** (玄风), ascending **Zhōngnán Shān** to restore the thatched pavilion, renaming it **Lóuguān** (楼观). He commissioned the **recluses Yǐn Guǐ** (尹轨), **Dù Chōng** (杜冲), and others to tend the shrine, numbering seven **Daoists** (道士) among them.

Later, **Lǎozǐ** (老子) returned eastward, passing through **Lóuguān**, where he transmitted the *Dàodé Zǐxū Yángguāng Jīngjù* (道德紫虚阳光经箓) to **Yǐn Guǐ, Dù Chōng, and Sòng Lún** (宋伦).

**Yóu Wáng** (幽王) summoned him to the post of **Grand Historian** (太史). In the third year, **Xīnyǒu** (辛酉), he warned the king of tremors in the **Three Rivers** (三川), foretelling the fall of **Zhōu** (周), and then vanished.

In the thirty-fourth year of **Píng Wáng’s** (平王) reign, **Guǐmǎo** (癸卯), he re-emerged through **Dàsàn Guān**, remaining in the central lands for some time before returning.

**Jìng Wáng** (敬王) appointed him **Keeper of the Hidden Archives** (藏室史) for eighteen years.

When **Kǒngzǐ** (孔子) arrived in **Zhōu** with **Nángōng Jìngshū** (南宫敬叔) to inquire about rites, **Yìliè Wáng** (夷烈王) in his second year granted him an audience. Passing through **Qín**, **Xiàn Gōng** (献公) of **Qín** hosted him with honors and consulted him on **astronomy and numerology** (历数).

In the ninth year of **Yǎn Wáng’s** (赧王) reign, **Lǎozǐ** traveled to **Rǔjǐ** (女几) in **Fèitiān Zhù** (肺天柱), from which point he again departed through **Dàsàn Guān**, crossing the **flowing sands** (流沙) and ascending **Kūnlún** (昆仑) in the west.

He lived **174 years** in the **Shāng** (商) and **822 years** in the **Zhōu** (周), wandering the world, aiding the age, and spanning **996 years** of human history. Yet those who view him only through the **Shāng** and **Zhōu** fail to grasp the **Tàishàng Lǎozǐ** (太上之老子). Those who perceive him merely as a figure of the human world—how could they comprehend the **Xiāntiān Lǎozǐ** (先天之老子)?

Thus the *Jīng* (经) states:
*"Independent yet unchanging, revolving yet unexhausted.*
*To wield the ancient Dao in governing the present—*
*Is this not the Master’s own self-expression?"*

As for the **Qín-Hàn** (秦汉) onward, down to the **Táng-Sòng** (唐宋), his **manifestations and transformations** (应身降现) were boundless—common folk could not recognize them. The *Běnjì* (本纪) and *Shílù* (实录) attest to this.

**Eight Chapters on Transmission:**
**Jiān Yǐnzǐ** (关尹子), surnamed **Yǐn** (尹), named **Xǐ** (喜), served **Zhāo Wáng** (昭王) as a **Great Official** (大夫). Skilled in **celestial omens** (天文), he foresaw that **true qi** (真气) from the southeast would manifest like a **dragon-serpent**, while the west would experience **threefold winds** (三扇) dispersing **heavenly order** (天理) westward. Knowing a **sage** (圣人) would cross the pass, he begged to be appointed **Orderly of Hángǔ Pass** (函谷关令).

In the fifth month, **Guǐchǒu** (癸丑), **Rénwǔ** (壬午), **purple vapors** (紫气) filled the sky. An **old man** (老人) drove a **green ox and white oxcart** (青牛白畚车), with disciples riding as outriders, **Xū Jiǎ** (徐甲) as charioteer, preparing to cross the pass. Jiān Yǐn Xī knelt in welcome, and it was **Lǎozǐ** (老子).

Jiān Yǐn Xī said, *"The Great Dao is about to vanish—strongly urge him to record it!"* Thus, he lodged at the **thatched pavilion of Zhōngnán** (终南草楼) and became his disciple.

The following year, **Jiǎyín** (甲寅), **Lǎozǐ** transmitted the *Dàodé* (道德) in **over five thousand words**, encompassing **heaven and earth**, harmonizing with **mysterious transformation** (造化), and exhaustively encompassing **sovereigns, ministers, people, and things**. He exalted **Dao and virtue** (道德) above **benevolence and righteousness** (仁义), thereby elevating the **Emperor** above petty **kings and lords** (王伯).

Fundamentally, he clarified the **Dao of Heaven** (天道) and the **Dao of Humanity** (人道), rectifying the **sovereign’s heart** (君心) and the **people’s heart** (民心). He declared:
*"Govern with rectitude, employ the extraordinary in warfare."*
*"The Left General commands the left, the Upper General commands the right."*

In several chapters, his teachings resemble the **praise and censure of the Five Hegemons** (五伯). Scholars doubt whether **Zhāo Wáng** had yet established hegemony, or if the transmission occurred in **Jìng Wáng’s** (敬王) time—yet they fail to recognize that **Kūnú** (昆吾), **Dà Péng** (大彭), and **Shǐ Wéi** (豕韦) already styled themselves **Hegemons** in the decline of **Xià** and **Shāng**. Observing **Zhāo Wáng’s** failure to return from the **Jiāng** (江), it was clear that even without the rise of **Qí, Chǔ, Qín, and Jìn**, the **spirit of hegemony** had already emerged. This is why the **sage’s** *Dàodé* (道德) integrates **both efficacy and principle**.

Examining the **Buckenham’s Star** (乾象河鼓三星), which governs the **three armies of the Son of Heaven**, the **central star** is the **Great General** (大将军), the **left star** the **Left General** (左将军), and the **right star** the **Right General** (右将军). The **Summer Officials** (夏官) record the **Upper Grand Marshal** (上大司马) commanding **five armies**, with **greater states** fielding **three armies**, as seen in the *Zhōu Lǐ* (周礼). The *Mù Wáng Nèi Zhuàn* (穆王内传) further states that when the king returned from his western expedition and ascended **Zhōngnán Shān**, restoring the thatched pavilion, it confirms the transmission occurred in **Zhāo Wáng’s** time.

Jiān Yǐn Xī himself authored **nine chapters**, titled *Guān Yǐnzǐ* (关尹子). Later, his disciple **Jìn Gōngsūn Xīn Jié** (晋公孙辛钘)—recorded as **Yán** (研) in the *Wú Yuè Chūnqiū* (吴越春秋)—studied under **Lǎozǐ**. In the second year of **Jìng Wáng’s** (敬王) reign, **Yán** traveled south, where **Píng Wáng** of **Chǔ** (楚平王) honored him with an audience and sought his teachings.

Later, he journeyed to **Yuè** (越), where **Fàn Lǐ** (范蠡) became his disciple. **Lǎozǐ** gave him **twelve chapters**, titled *Wénzǐ* (文子), including a section on **Píng Wáng’s** (平王) inquiry. **Gōujīàn** (勾践) elevated him to the rank of **Great Official** (大夫).

When **Yuè** attacked **Wú** (吴), **Fàn Lǐ** counseled:
*"War is a cruel instrument. Battle defies virtue. Secret plots defy virtue; favoring cruel tools—heaven forbids it. This course will not prosper."*
He cited the *Wénzǐ* (文子).

**Gōujīàn** refused, suffering defeat at **Fú Jiāo** (夫椒), imprisonment in the **Stone Chamber** (石室), and only returned after bribing the **Grand Steward Fú Pì** (太宰嚭).

After his defeat, **Gōujīàn** vowed vengeance and drank bitter herbs to steel his resolve. When he was confined in the marshes, **Jì Rán** said:
*"Gōujīàn has a long neck and a hawk’s beak—he may endure hardship with you, but he cannot share in peace."*

**Fàn Lǐ** followed this counsel, fleeing to the **Five Lakes**. **Jì Rán**, too, feigned madness and fled, taking refuge in **Fēngyú**, where he climbed mountains to devise strategies. This is the origin of the **Mountain Plans** now attributed to **Wú**.

**Liè Yùkòu** dwelled in **Jǐng’s** fields for forty years, yet no one recognized him. In the fourth year of **Ān Wáng’s** reign, he composed eight chapters, elucidating **Lǎozǐ’s** **Dao**.

**Zhuāng Zhōu**, styled **Zǐxiū** and surnamed **Nánhúazǐ**, in the thirty-third year of **Xiǎn Wáng’s** reign, was invited by **Chǔ** to serve as chancellor, but he declined. Instead, he secluded himself in the **Lacquer Garden** by the **Hú River**, compiling fifty-three chapters titled *Zhuāngzǐ*. Thirty-three remain today.

As for **Gēngsāng Chǔ**, **Nánhóng Qù**, **Cuī Qú**, **Mòjǔ**, **Shìchéng Qǐ**, and **Yín Wénzǐ**—all were disciples of **Lǎozǐ** in their time, transmitting his **Dao** and leaving their own writings recorded in the classics. Yet **Lǎozǐ** himself had long traversed **Shāng** and **Zhōu**. Those who saw him in person, like **Kǒngzǐ**, were few indeed.

Since **Sīmǎ Qiān** grouped **Lǎozǐ** and **Hàn Fēi** in a single biography, the records of **Lǎozǐ’s** disciples were lost, causing the **Dao** of **Kǒng** and **Lǎo**—once intertwined—to vanish without transmission in later ages. Alas.

This is the **"Western Journey" chapter**.

The **Venerable Sage of Lao** in his later years crossed the shifting sands and ascended to the **Kūnlún Mountains**, returning to the **Zǐwēi Palace** above, thus demonstrating his final departure. For what ends is what begins—like the four seasons in their cyclical succession.

Hence it is said:
*"When one’s deeds are complete and one’s name established, to withdraw is the Way of Heaven."*
*"To complete one’s deeds without claiming them ensures one’s name endures."*
*"To never lose one’s place is to endure; to die without perishing is to attain true longevity."*

Thus, the **Sage observes the Way of Heaven**, follows **Heaven’s course**, and in retreat and advance aligns with the **Creator’s boundless work**. The **Kūnlún Mountains** lie in the northwest of the earth, towering over ten thousand *lǐ*, vast in breadth. They reach toward the **Bìluò** (Celestial Vault), where the **Lí** people dwell. Hence, **Xīhuáng’s** **Gèn** and **Wénwáng’s** **Qián** both occupy the northwest.

As the **Kūnlún** is to the earth, so the **Yuánshǒu** is to man. The heavens rise highest in the northwest, where the **Heavenly Gate** stands. Its nine peaks pierce the nine heavens, where the **Most High** and the gathered **True Ones** ascend in revelry. There, **jewel-pine trees** and **jade flowers**, **qi-hua** and **yáo-grass**, seven-treasured forests sway in the **Heavenly Wind**, their **línláng** chimes resounding in perfect harmony—an uncarved realm of **Yù** (jade) and **Hún** (primordial sound).

The **Kūnlún** is the **Central Peak of Heaven**, situated between the northern seas, directly beneath the **Heavenly Heart**, shaped like an inverted canopy—broad at the top, narrow below, tiered in three layers, its summit touching the heavens. There, the **Yellow and Red Paths** of the sun and moon converge, and the **Three Luminaries** traverse. To the east lies **Kūnlún**, to the west **Xuánpǔ**, to the north **Yuèyuàn**, and to the south, the **Jīshí Mountains**, the **Zhènshuǐ Springs**, and the **Běihù Mountains** connect. Above stand the **Five Golden Platforms** and **Twelve Jade Pavilions**, encircled by a **Thousand-*lǐ* Golden City**.

There grow **golden-rooted trees**, **jade-branched forests**, **purple phoenixes**, **emerald cranes**, **azure peaches**, and **white plums** in abundance. The **Mìoyán**—the **Yellow Emperor’s Celestial Sovereign**—holds the **pivot and lock**, governing this mountain and linking it to the **Five Sacred Peaks**. Divine beings and immortals traverse it ceaselessly.

Examining the **registers of birth**, the **Upper Sovereign** resides here, the essence of the **Filling Stars**, dwelling within the **Central-*yī* Qi of Heaven**.

The **Five Peaks beyond the seas** are the **Five Pillars of Heaven and Earth**, the **Five Origins of the Five Qi**. The **Venerable Sage’s** ascent to **Kūnlún**—was it not a return to the **Wújí** (Non-Extreme)?

For **Kūnlún** is the dwelling of **Original Qi** and the realm of the **Celestial Sovereign**. In ancient times, **kings, rulers, marshals, and great ministers** who achieved great deeds and virtue, as well as **high men and virtuous scholars** with profound **Dao** and wondrous conduct, all ascended there. How could those who defy **Heaven’s Way** or stray from **Heaven’s course** ever hope to reach it?

Yet it is said that **immortals** are but **transferred**. Those who cultivate the **Dao**, like the **Three Teachings of the Han**—**Máojūn**, **Zhāng Fǔhàn**—or the **Jìn** scholars **Xǔ Jīngyáng** and **Gě Xiāngōng**, first ascended to the **Sacred Mountains**, then to the **Ten Isles and Three Expanse-Islands**, and finally to **Kūnlún** as **Supreme Celestial Officials**. Not only could they be counted among **Laozi’s** disciples, but they could be counted among **Heaven’s** disciples as well.

As the *Huáinánzǐ* states:
*"Yú dug into the **Kūnlún’s** foundations, revealing a nine-tiered palace a hundred thousand *lǐ* high. There grew **grain-trees** five *zhèn* tall, **pearl-trees**, **jade-trees**, **encircling-trees**, and **trees of immortality** to the west; **sand-peach** and **lángyáng** to the east; **crimson-trees** to the south; and **emerald-trees** and **yáo-trees** to the north. Four hundred forty gates flanked it, four *lǐ* between each gate, nine *chún* between each interval. Nine wells stood beside them, with **jade** lodged in the northwest corner. The northern gate opened to the **Bùzhōu Wind**, causing the **rotating halls** to sway, the **suspended orchards** to cool, and the **fān-tóng** to flourish within the **Kūnlún’s** gates—its **sparse gardens**. The gardens’ pools were filled with **Yellow Water**, which circled three times before returning to its source, called **Dan Water**; drinking it grants immortality.

The **River** issued from the **Kūnlún’s** northeast corner, flowing through the **Bóhǎi** into the **Jīshí Mountains** where **Yú** channeled it. The **Red Water** emerged from its southeast corner, flowing southwest into the **Southern Sea**. To the east of **Dānzé**, from the **Weak Water’s** source at **Qióngshí**, it reached **Hélí**, its excess spilling into the **Flowing Sands** and south to the **Southern Sea**. The **Yáng Water** issued from its northwest corner, entering the **Southern Sea** south of **Yǔmín**.

These four waters are the **Divine Springs of the Emperor**, blending all medicines and nourishing all things.

The **Kūnlún Hills**—some say double its height—are called the **Mountain of Cool Winds**, ascending which grants immortality. Others say double again, calling it **Xuánpǔ**, ascending which grants **spiritual potency**, enabling mastery over wind and rain. Doubling once more, it becomes **Shàngtiān** (Upper Heaven), ascending which grants **divinity**—the abode of the **Tàidì** (Great Sovereign).

**Original Title: Chapter Ten**

The *Dàodéjīng* was recorded by **Guān Lìng**, **Yǐnxí**, at the behest of the **Venerable Sage**. The **Sage’s** words encompass the **Way of Non-Beginning and Beginning**, the **Opening of Heaven and Establishment of the Pole**, the **Royal Dao of the Highest Antiquity**, the **Imperial Virtue of the Ancient Age**, down to the **kings’ deeds** and the **lords’ might—over five thousand characters**, encompassing the **Dao of Heaven and Man**, spanning thousands of generations, clearly traceable.

The **Sage** is spoken of in thirty-two instances without a name—perhaps the **Nameless Ancient Historian**. It serves as a **mirror for ten thousand ages**, a **framework for human perfection**, and a **path to enter the Sacred Realm**.

The **Venerable Sage** compiled the *Dàodéjīng* from **Ancient Histories**, just as the **Sage Kǒng** composed the *Chūnqiū* from **Lǔ Histories**—one in essence. Yet it is not called a *History* but the *Dàodéjīng*, for it follows the **trigram cycles**, as the **Outer Historians** of the **Zhōu Officials** recorded the **annals of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors**.

The *Sān Fén* having vanished and the *Wǔ Diǎn* incomplete, yet fortunately this *Jīng* remains, preserving the Ancient Way from decay.

The Venerable Sage’s intent was earnest: to proclaim the **Imperial Dao** and **Sovereign Virtue** as the true counsel for the age. With kings and lords arising in competition, their deeds and might vying, he feared their ultimate ruin and the people’s helplessness. Thus, he sought to restore fragmentation into wholeness, to return corruption to purity—even if he could not make the people into the **Nine Sovereigns’ subjects**, could he not at least let them glimpse the **harmonious transformations of Tāng and Yú**?

Alas, the Sage was of Heaven. Heaven’s mind is the Sage’s mind. Heaven’s Way is the Sage’s Way. Heaven does not act for itself but entrusts it to the Sage; thus Heaven may remain without action. The Sage does not act for himself but entrusts it to the **Worthy**; thus the Sage may remain without action. But the Worthy must act.

The Sage acts without action above; the Worthy acts with action below—thus the **Dao of Sovereign and Minister** is fulfilled. Hence it is said: *"Act by non-action."* Again: *"Non-action yet nothing remains undone"*—for the **distinction of Sovereign and Minister** lies therein. The people’s steadfastness is where their **endeavors** reside.

In the **Great Primordial Age**, the **Mystic Wind** unified the Way under Heaven. In the **Xīhuáng’s flourishing era**, the **Four Seas shared one Virtue**—this was the **non-action** that, in truth, was the **greatest action** for the world.

Though spoken of as *"non-action"* and *"action"*, its essence is **human-hearted Heavenly Principle**, all contributing to **wealth and transformation**. As for those who speak of the Sage without naming Him—was it not the **Nameless Sovereigns of the Great Primordial Age**, or the Sovereigns **Xī, Xuān, Yáo, and Shùn**?

To honor the Ancient Sage is to honor the present Sovereign and his age; to prolong this Way is to prolong this world.

**Chapter Sentences of the *Dàodéjīng***
The *Chapter Sentences* of the *Dàodé* were composed by **Hé Shànggōng**.

When Emperor Wén of Hán valued **tranquility and stillness**, he commanded the court scholars to study the *Lǎozǐ*, yet no annotated text existed. Its language was profound and abstruse, much of it unclear. He heard of an old man in the **Shǎn-Hé region** who mastered the *Lǎozǐ*, so he sent an envoy to inquire. The old man presented the Emperor with a plain-text copy of the *Lǎozǐ*, clarified its meaning, and divided it into **eighty-one chapters**, each marked with two characters to elucidate its essence—such as *"Cultivating the Dao"*, *"Nurturing the Body"*, *"Calming the People"*, and the like. From these *Chapter Sentences*, commentaries arose.

Yet as the Way descended with the ages, interpretations varied. Commentators followed the trends of their times, each shaping the text to their own convictions. Thus, the **Hán commentators** produced the *Hán Lǎozǐ*, the **Jìn** the *Jìn Lǎozǐ*, the **Táng** the *Táng Lǎozǐ*, and the **Sòng** the *Sòng Lǎozǐ*. Some spoke of **emptiness and non-action**; others of **breathing techniques and guided movements**; still others of **nature, fate, fortune, misfortune, warfare, and statecraft**. Their explanations diverged like bells, each school claiming its own method—none grasping the **original intent of Dao and Virtue**, nor the **essential principle of Inner Sage and Outer King**. Thus, they failed to illuminate one another but instead contradicted, alas!

Even **Guān Zhòng** and **Wén Zǐ**, who had glimpsed the **Dragon’s essence**, wrote works that strayed from their masters’ teachings. **Liè Zǐ** and **Zhuāng Zǐ**, though close in time, diverged—**Liè** emphasizing **emptiness and stillness**, **Zhuāng** veering toward **profound and distant**—nearly transcending humanity, yet falling short of Heaven. Later, **Sūn Bīn** and **Wú Qí** distorted it into **martial strategy**, while **Shēn Bùhài** and **Hán Fēizǐ** twisted it into **legalist scheming**—truly, **human yet not Heavenly**. No wonder, after a thousand years, none could verify its truth.

Yet **Gāi Kē** and **Cáo Cān** practiced **tranquility and unity**, thereby establishing the **Hán dynasty’s prosperous peace**—these were true practitioners of the *Lǎozǐ*’s Way.

Now, observing **Hé Shànggōng’s** division into chapters, though his interpretations were **ethereal and profound**, they aligned with the *Jīng*’s essence. Yet his chapter titles lacked elucidation, leaving those who sought governance in confusion. Thus, this *Original Meaning* was composed.

Now, instead of recording the chapter titles, the *Jīng* itself is honored. As for their meanings, they are expounded within the *Original Meaning*, and the chapter titles are thus incorporated into a single exposition.

**Compile Mysterious Chapters (Twelve)**

**The Compilation of Mysterious Chapters**
**Mysterious Compilation** is the pivot and essence of the Five Thousand Words.

The **Laozi** said:
*"Words have a source; deeds have a master."* This means that all my sayings have their origin, and their foundations can be traced back to the words of ancient sages.

*Deeds are easy to know and easy to practice—yet why does the world fail to know them or practice them?*

**Zhongni** (Confucius) revered the teachings of **Yao** and **Shun**, and followed the constitutional models of **King Wen** and **King Wu**. Though they share the same source, their names differ. Once they are seen, one inquires about **ritual** (*li*). Then, in retreat, one privately compares them.

*If one faithfully recounts the ancient teachings and trusts in antiquity, one must have insight into that era.*

Now, with the creation of *The Origin of Intentions* (*Yuánzhǐ*), having already expounded its meaning, I further distinguish its principles in separate sentences. Thus, those who study **Mysterious Compilation** may verify sentences through categories, verify chapters through sentences, and verify meanings through chapters. Perhaps then the original intent of the **Mysterious Sage** may be made clear to all under heaven and to future generations.

*Those who speak of governing the Dao/Way—how can they afford to neglect it?*

**The Dao/Way that can be spoken of**—
*The Dao/Way that can be spoken of is not the eternal Dao/Way.*
*The Dao/Way that endures is the Dao/Way of longevity and clear vision.*
*The Dao/Way of Heaven’s law is the Dao/Way of natural law.*
*Those of high virtue who hear the Dao/Way diligently practice it.*
*The Dao/Way of clarity is like darkness.*
*The Dao/Way of smoothness is like ruggedness.*
*The Dao/Way of advancement is like retreat—better to sit and progress in this Dao/Way.*
*Seeing the Dao/Way without peering through windows means seeing the Heavenly Dao/Way.*
*The Dao/Way of action is daily diminished.*
*The Dao/Way of the Sage is to act without striving.*
*Thus, all things honor the Dao/Way and attribute virtue/power to it.*

*The Heavenly Dao/Way completes its function, attains its name, and withdraws—this is the Heavenly Dao/Way.*
*The Heavenly Dao/Way does not strive yet triumphs effortlessly.*
*The Heavenly Dao/Way has no favorites, always aiding the virtuous.*
*The Heavenly Dao/Way benefits without harming.*
*The Heavenly Dao/Way diminishes excess and supplements deficiency.*
*But the human Dao/Way is otherwise: it diminishes deficiency to honor excess.*
*Ancient Dao/Way—those who held the ancient Dao/Way were the ancient ones who excelled in the Dao/Way. Why did the ancients value this Dao/Way?*
*See above for the Dao/Way’s honor.*

*Those who possess the Dao/Way do not dwell in the world.*
*Those who possess the Dao/Way turn away even the finest horses to dung—who else can diminish excess to benefit the world? Only those who possess the Dao/Way.*

*The Great Dao/Way, once abandoned, gives rise to benevolence and righteousness.*
*The Great Dao/Way, once lost, can be found on either side.*
*The Great Dao/Way is most smooth, yet people prefer narrow paths.*
*If I were to know this clearly, I would walk the Great Dao/Way.*
*See above for the practice of the Dao/Way.*

*The Dao/Way that is not the Dao/Way has already perished.*
*What is not the Dao/Way is not the Dao/Way at all.*
*Losing the Dao/Way, one then attains virtue/power.*
*The Dao/Way’s beginning can know the ancient origin—this is called the Dao/Way’s beginning.*
*The Dao/Way’s splendor is the beginning of wisdom, yet the beginning of foolishness.*
*The Dao/Way’s profundity—those who grasp the Dao/Way are the profound ones. The Dao/Way of all things is profound; the honor of the Dao/Way is supreme.*

*The Dao/Way’s law is natural law.*
*The Dao/Way’s constancy—constancy without name, constancy without action yet accomplishing all actions.*
*The Dao/Way’s generation—generation that generates all things.*

**Virtue/Power**
*Broad virtue/power—broad virtue/power seems insufficient.*
*Established virtue/power—established virtue/power seems like a rank.*
*Accumulated virtue/power—early service is called heavy planting of virtue/power.*
*Those with virtue/power govern through trust.*
*Those without virtue/power govern through strictness.*
*The virtue/power of **Kong** (*Confucius*)—the bearing of **Kong**’s virtue/power.*
*All things honor the Dao/Way and value virtue/power.*
*The Mysterious virtue/power endures yet is not slaughtered—this is called Mysterious virtue/power.*
*Always knowing the models—this is called Mysterious virtue/power.*
*The constancy of virtue/power never strays, returning again to the infant.*
*The constancy of virtue/power never errs, returning again to the boundless.*
*When virtue/power is sufficient, it returns again to simplicity.*

*The virtue/power of the highest—*
*The highest virtue/power does not claim virtue/power.*
*The highest virtue/power acts without striving yet accomplishes nothing without action.*
*The highest virtue/power is like a valley.*

*The virtue/power of the lowest—*
*The lowest virtue/power does not lose virtue/power.*
*The lowest virtue/power acts with striving and accomplishes something.*
*The virtue/power that does not strive—*
*Those who do not strive for virtue/power attain the highest virtue/power—this is called the virtue/power of non-striving.*

*Virtue/power in harmony—*
*Those who harmonize with virtue/power are in virtue/power.*
*Those who harmonize with virtue/power, virtue/power also attains them.*
*The true virtue/power is cultivated in the body—then its virtue/power is true.*
*The virtue/power of abundance is cultivated in the home—then its virtue/power is abundant.*
*The virtue/power of length is cultivated in the village—then its virtue/power is long.*
*The virtue/power of fullness is cultivated in the state—then its virtue/power is full.*
*The virtue/power of universality is cultivated throughout the world—then its virtue/power is universal.*
*The virtue/power of depth is the depth of virtue/power.*
*The virtue/power of goodness—even those who are not good, I also treat as good: this is virtue/power of goodness.*
*The virtue/power of trust—even those who are not trustworthy, I also trust: this is virtue/power of trust.*
*The virtue/power of nurturing—nurturing virtue/power.*
*The virtue/power of nobility—noble virtue/power.*

**Before Heaven**
*Before Heaven, there was the **mysterious substance** (*hun*) formed in unity.*
*Before Heaven and Earth, there was generation.*
*Boundless returns again to boundless.*
*To reach the utmost emptiness, one must guard stillness with sincerity.*
*Ancient emptiness is called matching Heaven—this is the ancient emptiness.*
*Without beginning, without name—this is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.*
*Ancient beginning can know the ancient beginning—this is called the Dao/Way’s beginning.*
*With beginning, the world has a mother.*
*Without form—this is the form of the formless.*
*With form—dim and vague, yet within it, there is form.*
*The Great Form—*
*The Great Form has no shape; yet those who grasp the Great Form move all under Heaven.*
*The Form precedes—this is the Form before the **Emperor** (*Di*).*
*Unity in the Mysterious—*
*Unity is called the Mysterious.*
*Again, the Mysterious of the Mysterious—*
*Deep and obscure, yet within it, there is essence.*
*Dim and vague, yet within it, there are things.*
*The root of Heaven and Earth—this is called the root of Heaven and Earth.*
*The gate of all wonders—this is called the gate of all wonders.*
*The Mysterious Mother—this is called the Mysterious Mother.*
*The source of all things—this is called the source of all things.*

**Heaven and Earth**
*Heaven and Earth without substance are called the beginning of Heaven and Earth.*
*Heaven and Earth without benevolence regard all things as fodder and dogs.*
*Between Heaven and Earth, it is like a bellows.*
*The Mysterious Mother is called the root of Heaven and Earth.*
*Heaven endures long, Earth endures long—who can do this?*
*Heaven and Earth in unity descend sweet dew.*
*Heaven gains **Oneness** (*Yī*) and becomes clear; Earth gains **Oneness** (*Yī*) and becomes tranquil.*

**All Things**
*All things with substance are called the mother of all things.*
*All things act yet do not speak.*
*Deep and obscure, like the source of all things.*
*Water benefits all things yet does not strive.*
*All things arise together, yet I observe their return.*
*All things will naturally come as guests.*
*All things rely upon it to live yet do not speak.*

**Nurturing All Things**

Nurture all things yet claim no mastery.
All things will transform of their own accord.
All things gain **Oneness** (*Yī*) and thrive.
The myriad things arise from existence.

Three transformations give birth to all things;
All things bear yin yet embrace yang.
All things follow the **Dao** and cherish virtue.
Grass and wood in their growth are soft and frail.

No thing returns to nothingness.
Things arise from the mingling of things.
Strange things arise from strange things.
Things grow strong yet grow old.

The myriad names do not depart,
To observe the myriad names.
**The World**

When all under Heaven know beauty as beauty,
Then ugliness already exists.
To value oneself for all under Heaven,
As if one could entrust all under Heaven.
To love oneself for all under Heaven,
As if one could commit all under Heaven.

Thus, the Sage embraces **Oneness**,
Setting the model for all under Heaven.
Can become the mother of all under Heaven.
Yet lightens himself for all under Heaven.
Becomes the valley for all under Heaven.
Sets the model for all under Heaven.

To take all under Heaven and act upon it—
All under Heaven is a sacred vessel.
Do not use force to conquer all under Heaven.
Cannot fulfill one’s will in all under Heaven.
All under Heaven dare not submit.

**The Dao** in all under Heaven—
Holding the great image, all under Heaven turns toward it.
All under Heaven will self-correct.
The sovereign who gains **Oneness**,
Makes it the standard for all under Heaven.

All under Heaven’s myriad things arise from existence.
The utmost softness of all under Heaven,
Gallops over the utmost firmness of all under Heaven.
Few can attain it.
Clarity and stillness govern all under Heaven.
To take all under Heaven, always act without action.

When all under Heaven is in **Dao**,
Warhorses are driven out to till the fields.
When all under Heaven is without **Dao**,
Warhorses breed in the suburbs.

The Sage in all under Heaven—
Dull and indistinct, blending the hearts of all under Heaven.
Cultivating all under Heaven, virtue becomes universal.
Viewing all under Heaven with all under Heaven,
Thus, all under Heaven honors the Sage.
Taking all under Heaven with non-action.

All under Heaven abounds in taboos,
Yet the people grow poorer.
Rule all under Heaven with **Dao**,
And its spirits lose their power.

Great nations flow downward,
The confluence of all under Heaven.
Difficult tasks arise from ease,
Great affairs arise from small.

Thus, all under Heaven finds joy in advancing without weariness.
Only by not contending
Does all under Heaven find none who can contend with it.
Dare not lead all under Heaven.
All under Heaven cannot know, cannot act.
Who can, with abundance, serve all under Heaven?

Nothing under Heaven is softer or weaker than water,
Yet it can reign over all under Heaven.

**States**

States with many sharp tools grow corrupt.
States in chaos have loyal ministers.
A state with its mother-state can endure long.
Neighboring states face one another.

To govern a state and love its people,
Can one truly act without action?
Rule with rectitude.
Govern a great state as one would cook a small fish.
To govern with knowledge is the ruin of the state.
To govern without knowledge is the state’s blessing.

Great states flow downward,
The confluence of all under Heaven.
Great states subdue small states, then take them.
Great states desire only to nurture the people.
Small states submit to great states, then are taken.
Small states desire only to serve others.
Few people, few desires.

Cultivate the state, and its virtue becomes abundant.
Cultivate the family, and its virtue overflows.
Cultivate the village, and its virtue endures.
Observe the village by the village.
Observe the state by the state.
Observe the family by the family.

**The Most High**

The Most High knows what exists.
The Sage thus acts in non-action.
Thus, the Sage’s governance—
The Sage is not benevolent.
Thus, the Sage places himself last yet leads first.
Thus, the Sage acts for the belly, not the eyes.
Thus, the Sage embraces **Oneness** as the model for all under Heaven.
Thus, the Sage is always ready to save others.

The Sage uses them, and they become officials.
Thus, the Sage rejects excess, rejects extravagance, rejects excessiveness.
Thus, the Sage never becomes great.
Thus, the Sage acts without moving, yet knows.
The Sage has no fixed mind.
The Sage in all under Heaven—
All are like children.
Thus, the Sage says:
*"I act without action, yet the people transform of their own accord."*

Thus, the Sage is square yet not rigid.
The Sage does not harm others.
Thus, the Sage is difficult to approach.
The Sage’s non-action brings no failure.
Thus, the Sage desires without desiring.
Thus, the Sage desires to be above others,
Yet speaks to them from below.
Thus, the Sage is above yet the people do not feel burdened.
Thus, the Sage wears coarse cloth yet holds jade within.
The Sage is without illness.

Thus, the Sage knows himself yet does not display himself.
Thus, the Sage acts yet does not rely on it.
Thus, the Sage says:
*"The Sage holds the left contract yet does not demand repayment from others."*

The Sage does not accumulate.
The Sage’s **Dao** acts yet does not contend.

**Rulers and Ministers**

The Son of Heaven establishes the Son of Heaven,
Appoints the Three Ministers.
The King is great, the King is great.
The King of Heaven is Heaven itself.
The King of Heaven is called the King of all under Heaven.

The sovereign who aids the sovereign with **Dao**
Does not use force to conquer all under Heaven.
The lord of ten thousand chariots—
How can the lord of ten thousand chariots
Lighten himself for all under Heaven?

The lord of the ancestral altars is called the lord of the ancestral altars.
The official who does not dare lead all under Heaven first
Can thus fulfill the role of official.

The Sage uses them, and they become officials.
To match Heaven is called matching Heaven,
The ancient ultimate.

The nobles and ministers are called "orphan," "widow," "not-grain," yet they are titled thus.

The Duke is a Duke, the King is a King.
The Three Ministers are appointed.
The feudal lords—if they can guard **Oneness**,
The feudal lords gain **Oneness**,
Making it the standard for all under Heaven.
The feudal lords do not rely on rectitude to be noble and high.
The feudal lords call themselves "orphan," "widow," "not-grain."
Thus, they can be kings of the myriad grains.

The ruler’s words have a lineage,
Affairs have a sovereign.
Hastiness loses the sovereign.
Lightness loses the minister.
Though crude, the state dares not submit.

**Scholars and Gentlemen**

The virtuous scholar of antiquity—
Subtle, mysterious, profound, and penetrating.

The virtuous scholar does not rely on force.

The **Upper Scholar**—when the Upper Scholar hears the **Dao**, he is diligent in practicing it.
The **Middle Scholar**—when the Middle Scholar hears the **Dao**, it is as if it exists, as if it does not.
The **Lower Scholar**—when the Lower Scholar hears the **Dao**, he laughs it off.

Thus, the **Noble**—the **Noble** walks all day without leaving his baggage.
Thus, the **Noble** dwells and honors the left.

Warfare is an inauspicious instrument;
It is not the instrument of the **Noble**.

The **Great Man**—the **Great Man** abides in substance, not in superficiality.

**Father and Son**
Teaching as a father—*I will teach as a father*.
The **Six Kins**—when the **Six Kins** are not harmonious, there is filial piety and kindness.
Filial piety and kindness sever **ren** and abandon **righteousness**—yet the people return to filial piety and kindness.
The **Mother of the State**—the **Mother of the State** can endure forever.
The **Mother of All Under Heaven**—the **Mother of All Under Heaven** has its origin, and thus becomes the **Mother of All Under Heaven**.
The **Mother of All Things**—the **Mother of All Things** is named the **Mother of All Things**.
**Food’s Mother**—**Food’s Mother** is honored, and food is sought from her.
When **Mother and Child** obtain their **Mother**, they know their **Child**.
When **Child and Mother** know their **Child**, they return to guard their **Mother**.
The **Infant**—the **Infant** gathers **qi** and attains softness.
Can one be like the **Infant**?
Constantly obtaining without separation, returning to the **Infant**.
*Buoyant, buoyant*—like the **Infant** before it becomes a child.
The **Unformed Child** sees the **Upper**.
The **Child**—all **Sages** are **Children**.
The **Innocent Babe** contains the depth of **virtue**, compared to the **Innocent Babe**.
**Descendants**—descendants do not cease their sacrifices.

**Male and Female**—knowing the **Female**, guarding the **Male**.
**Female and Male**—before knowing **Female and Male**, they unite and act.

**Teachers and Learning**
The **Teacher** does not value his **Teacher**; he does not cherish his **resources**.
A **Teacher of Goodness** is not the **Teacher** of the unvirtuous.
The **Great Artisan**—the **Great Artisan** succeeds the **Great Artisan** in hewing.

**Learning and Composition**
**Learning**—daily increase.
**Composition**—insufficient for **composition**.
**Non-learning**—**Non-learning** repeats the errors of the multitude.
**Abandoning Learning**—**Abandoning Learning** brings no worry.
**Patterns**—constantly knowing **Patterns**, this is called **Mysterious Virtue**.

**Host and Guest**
The **Host** does not dare to be **Host** but becomes **Guest**.

The myriad things return to it yet it does not claim lordship.
It nurtures all things yet does not claim lordship.
As **Guest** to all things, all things will become **Guest** in turn.
As **Guest**, solemn as a **Guest**, rejoicing with those who feast—
when **Guests** depart, they are stopped.

**The People**
The **Good Person**—**Dao** has no favorites, yet always aligns with the **Good Person**.
The **Good Person** is not the **Teacher** of the unvirtuous.
**Dao** is the hidden essence of all things,
the treasure of the **Good Person**,
the refuge of the unvirtuous.
The unvirtuous see only the exalted.

The **Strange Person**—I alone am strange among people.
The **Fool**—I am the heart of the **Fools**!
The **Multitude**—the **Multitude** bustles and thrives.
The **Multitude** all have excess.
The **Multitude** all have means to repay.
The **Multitude**’s errors.

The **Vulgar**—the **Vulgar** shine brightly.
The **Vulgar** are keenly observant.
To **save**—always **save** the people well,
thus there are no abandoned.
The abandoned see only the exalted.

To **govern**—to **govern** affairs with **Heaven**,
nothing surpasses **frugality**.
The **slayer**—those who delight in **slaying**,
cannot achieve their ambitions in the world.
Many **slayings** bring sorrow and weeping.

To **know**—the **knower** of people is wise.
To **overcome**—the **overcomer** of people has strength.
To **show**—the **utilities** of the state,
one must not display them to the people.
To **employ**—the **employer** of people,
if he acts as the inferior, will succeed.
To **give**—if one gives to others,
the more one gives, the more one possesses.
To **lead**—do not exalt the worthy,
do not stir contention among the people.
Do not prize rare goods,
so the people will not steal.
Do not display what is desirable,
so the people’s hearts will not be disordered.
Always keep the people in ignorance and without desire.
If you make the people always fear death as something strange,
make them value death so they do not flee far,
make them return to simple bonds and use them.
To **love** the people—**love** the people to **govern** the state,
how could one fail to act with **Non-Action**?

To **enlighten**—not to **enlighten** the people,
but to **delude** them.
The common folk treat the common folk as sacrificial dogs.
When the work is accomplished and the task fulfilled,
the common folk will all say, *"It was natural."*
The common folk will all focus their ears and eyes.
Not blaming others—thus the **Sage** holds the left contract
and does not blame others.

**Military Affairs**
The **General**—the **General** of the left **General** is positioned left,
the **Supreme General** is positioned right.

「The Great Army, the Great Army must be followed by years of calamity.
The finest soldiers, the finest soldiers—weapons of ill omen.
The enemy army, if one has no enemy, one holds no arms.
Even if there are arms of battle, they are not put to use.
Entering the army without bearing arms of defense.
Using arms through the **Dao** of **strangeness**—using arms.

When using arms, there is a saying:
One does not dare to be the aggressor but only the defender.
When opposing armies meet in battle, the weary will prevail.
When arms are strong, they will not prevail.
Where the army encamps, thorns and brambles will grow.
Hunting and galloping in the wilds will drive men’s hearts to madness.

**Bandits**
Bandits, if they abandon cunning and forsake profit,
then bandits will not exist.
If laws and decrees multiply, then bandits will abound.
The clever bandit, if he governs the state with his **virtue/power**,
is the ruin of the state.
A man who boasts of his wealth and surplus goods—
this is called **boasting as a bandit**.

**Ghosts and Spirits**
Ghosts and spirits, if they rule the world with the **Dao/Way**,
their ghosts will not be divine.
The divine and holy do not harm others—
they are not truly divine.
The **Sage** also does not harm others.
Divine **qi**—the **Sage** attains unity and thus is divine.
Without unity, his **qi** will falter, and he will fear exhaustion.
The body—
**Empty the heart**, emptying its heart.
The **Sage** has no fixed heart.
To take a heart, let it be the heart of the people.
To **muddle the heart**, let it be muddled for all under heaven.
The people’s hearts—do not let the people’s hearts be disordered.
The heart’s **qi**—when the heart commands the **qi**, it is called **strength**.
Weaken the will—weaken their will.
With a strong will, they will act forcefully.
**Strengthen the bones**—strengthen their bones.
When bones are weak, they are weak, yet sinews are supple and grip is firm.
When sinews are supple, they see the **Supreme** [or **Highest**].
With great **strength**, they can overcome others—
this is called **using the people’s strength**.
**Lead by example**—when the body leads, it is called **leading by example**.
**Preserve the body**—when the body is safeguarded externally, it is called **preserving the body**.」

「The body’s calamities leave no remnant of calamity.
The body retreats—achievements are fulfilled, name secured—the body retreats.
To have a body is my great affliction, for I have a body.
Without a body, even if I lose my body, what affliction do I have?
A lifetime of blocking its **mouth** (兑),
closing its **gate** (門),
yet a lifetime of no exertion.
Opening its **mouth** (兑),
completing its affairs,
yet a lifetime of no salvation.

**Cultivate the body**—cultivate the body itself,
then its **virtue/power** (德) becomes true.
**Honor the body**—honor the body for all under heaven.
**Love the body**—love the body for all under heaven.
**Afflicted by the body**—hold great affliction as if it were the body.
**Perish with the body**—the Dao endures long; perish with the body, yet do not fail.
**Harm the hands**—though the great artisan may hew,
rarely does one harm their hands.
**Drive away the arms**—drive away without arms,
then drive away the arms and yet persist.
**Fill the belly**—fill the belly.
**For the belly**—for the belly, not for the eyes.
**For the eyes**—see the **Supreme** (上).
**Blind the eyes**—blind to the five colors, making the eyes blind.
**Deafen the ears**—deaf to the five sounds, making the ears deaf.
**Dulled the mouth**—dulled to the five flavors, making the mouth dulled.
**The mouth’s flavor**—the Dao’s expression through the mouth,
so bland it has no taste.

**Sexual essence** (精)—**sexual essence** (精) arises before the union of male and female,
this is the utmost **sexual essence** (精).
**Ultimate sexual essence** (精至)—see the **Supreme** (上).
**Thousand-mile journey**—begin at the feet.

**Nature and life** (性命):
**Valley spirit** (谷神)—**valley spirit** (谷神) does not die,
this is called the **mysterious female** (玄牝).
**Qi of the void** (冲气)—**qi of the void** (冲气) harmonized,
**Concentrated qi** (专气)—concentrate the **qi** (氣) to achieve softness.
**True sexual essence** (精真)—within it, there is **sexual essence** (精),
its **sexual essence** (精) is most true.
**Restore life** (复命)—restoration called **restore life** (复命),
**restore life** (复命) is called **constancy** (常).
**Nurture spirit** (营魄)—nurture spirit, embrace **Oneness** (一),
how could it ever depart?
**Brightness and clarity** (光明)—use its brightness, return to its clarity.
**Glow without ostentation** (光耀)—glow while not dazzling.
**Hold the center** (守中)—guard the center steadfastly.
**Grasp firm**—grasp firm though bones are weak and sinews supple.
**Embrace Oneness** (抱一)—embrace **Oneness** (一),
how could it ever depart?
**Embrace Oneness** (抱一)—for all under heaven as a model.
**Mingle with Oneness** (混一)—thus mingling back to **Oneness** (一).

**Life and death** (生死):
**Life and death**—born from death, entering death.
Those who cling to life are doomed to death.
Human life—moving toward death’s ground.
The soft and yielding are those who cling to life.
The rigid and strong are doomed to death.
**Life from non-life**—life arises from non-life.
**Dao’s life**—the Dao generates **Oneness** (一).
**The first life**—before heaven and earth were born, the Dao was born.
**Generating life**—generating life with its boundless abundance.
**Preserve life**—truly, those who hear of preserving life:
**Seek life**—seek life with its utmost clarity.
**Mutual life**—life’s mutual reliance on having and not having.
**Long life**—long life comes from not self-generating life,
thus one can achieve long life.
This is called the Dao of deep roots and firm foundations,
long life and enduring vision.

**Disdain life**—do not disdain what you have been born into.
**Non-life**—truly, only those who do not take life as life are wise beyond valuing life.
**Honor life**—see above.
**Not dying**—**valley spirit** (谷神) does not die,
this is called the **mysterious female** (玄牝).
**Non-death**—with its non-death ground.

In the beginning of antiquity, everyone was Laozi, every home held virtue and Dao.
Words could not be heard—how could there be five thousand words as scripture?

The Great Uncarved Block scattered; the Original Scripture gathered the seven.
A sage traversed Shang and Zhou, laughing at strife and contention, imagining the Great Court’s irrecoverable loss.
Thus, he spoke five thousand words to expound ancient principles and rectify the mind.

The Blue Ox departed far; subtle words were buried, five thousand words expanded into tens of thousands.
To exhaust the Dao’s virtue, making it vast.

The True Person coexisted with the Three Sovereigns—
Surely he did not write books, lest later ages exhaust Hanwen and Gai Gong.
Thus, the Original Doctrine’s book also does not emerge from today’s Riverbank.

This book, from before Heaven, has twelve chapters, standing alone as a text.
Opening and closing ancient and modern, weaving logic and numbers,
Grasping the Gate’s intent, gathering the Great Achievement of Mystic Learning.

「He who reads this text shall stand in awe of the **Hongmeng** (the primal chaos of creation), and find himself naturally attuned to the **Jiande** (the Virtue of the Lord on High).
The past and present fade away, the self and the world are both forgotten—
just as **Yuanming** (Xian Zhi) ascended to **Xihuang** (the Dao of the Primordial Sovereign),
or sought the **Weiyin** (the awe-inspiring resonance) of the **Chanzong** (Zen Patriarchs).

The **Taiji** (Great Polarity) of **Mao Shou** (Master Mao of the Zhou) was originally **Wuji** (Non-Polarity).
Though it unfolded with **wuyun** (flourish and decline), the ancient and modern remain undivided.

The **Dao** (Way) and its arts may diverge,
yet the **universe** (Tianren) has but one body—
how can one know that **Laozi** (the Old Master) was not **Zisheng** (the First Sage)?
And how can one know that **Zisheng** (the First Sage) was not **I**?

In the midst of **Bai Shidongtian** (White Stone Cave’s celestial realm),
where water gleams and mountains rise,
I take up my staff and bow three times,
for those who inquire shall surely trace it back to me.

The **Lu Mountain Daoist, Huang Shigong** (Master Huang of Yellow Stone) respectfully dedicates this book.

Did the people truly have a beginning?

To open things and complete undertakings,
beyond the **thirteen gua** (trigrams) there is no further account,
yet the records of **Yunhuo** (Cloud Fire), **Shuili** (Water and Land), **Long** (Dragon), and **Niao Shi** (Bird Master)
and **Zishouzi** (Master Zhi of the Chen) bear witness to its truth.

Thus, **Zhuang Zhou**’s discourse on **Rongcheng** (Nourishing Perfection) and the twelve **Shi** (Sages),
was it not a **yuyan** (allegorical tale)?

Before **Huangdi** (the Yellow Emperor), there were seven **Tai** (Great) who ascended Mount Tai—
were they not **yicuo** (imagined conjecture)?

The **Five Sovereigns** (Wutai) initiated change,
and **three transformations** (San San) took root.
When the **Nine Ages** (Jiuzhi) concluded, the **Jia calendar** (Jia calendar system) emerged—
one can trace its origin,
and glimpse its subtle traces—
only in the **Book of Huangji** (the *Huangjing*) and the **Laozi** (the *Laozi*) does this remain.

Yet when I ponder it,
the **Yuanhui** (Great Cycle), **Yunshi** (Evolution of the World), and **Dayan** (Great Year) are vast,
while **years, months, days, and times** are minute.

The division of **Huangdi** (the Yellow Emperor) and **Wangbo** (the August Sovereign),
the fulfillment of opening and closing things—
its essence can be examined.

**Dayi** (Day of Jia), **Monthi** (Month of Yi), **Xinggui** (Star of Gui),
mark the age of **Shaohao** (Minor Hao),
and the **Jiazi** (Jia-Zi) calendar begins.

**Dayi** (Day of Jia), **Monthwu** (Month of Wu), **Xingjia** (Star of Jia),
signify the day of **Xia Yu** (Great Yu of Xia),
and the **Wangdao** (Way of the Kings) takes form.

Yet then, from the **6480 years** hence,
the reckoning breaks at **Yao** (Emperor Yao).

From **Jiachen** (Jia-Chen) onward—
were there no events worthy of record?
It is merely that **strategies and documents** (jiance) were lost and scattered,
and though raised, they lack confirming evidence—
this is why **Yao**’s deeds were omitted.

**Du Zunsheng** (Master Du of the Southern Valley),
a **Daoist** (Dao) spanning two dynasties,
his learning delving into ancient origins,
once declared that the **eight gua of one’s person** (Yibing Ba Gua),
were the signs of **Pangu opening Heaven** (Pangu’s creation of the cosmos),
and the **dawn and night of a day** (Dan-Ye),
the distinction between opening and closing things.

Thus, I gathered the **Nine Ages** (Jiuzhi) from ancient histories and calendars,
and cross-referenced them with **Laozi**’s subtle meanings,
to trace back to the **first, middle, and latter Three Sovereigns** (Sanhuang San San),
and connect them to the **established human extreme** (Renji) of **Huangdi** (the Yellow Emperor).

By this method, one can find
the **original intent** (Yuanshi) of the *Huangjing* (Book of Huangji),
and its purpose is to **revere the Sovereign’s Dao** (Huangdao) and **praise the Emperor’s virtue** (Dide).

I titled this book *Expounding the Original Intent* (Yuanshi Faxi),
divided into twelve chapters.

The first six chapters conclude with the **Zhou** (Zhou Dynasty),
the latter six expound on **Laozi**’s (the Old Master) beginning and end.

In essence, it reveals that **Laozi**’s (the Old Master) person was **Cangshi** (Hidden Historian),
his **five thousand words** (Wuyan) encompassing all the books of the **Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors** (Sanhuang Wudi),
with **profound words** (Xian) and **deep intent** (Suishi),
a **Cangshi** (Hidden Historian) without name in antiquity—
thus I took them to supplement **Shaozi** (Master Shao’s) unexpressed accounts,
and perhaps this is the book that humanity ought to have.

A disciple of **Laozi** (the Old Master), I say:
Words that touch upon **Heaven and Man** (Tianren) are beyond reach,
yet if rulers of states grasp his teachings and apply them,
then the **sovereign** (Jun) shall be **youshu** (auspicious and harmonious) above,
and the **ministers** (Chen) shall be **minxing** (responsive and sensitive) below—
thus the people shall be nurtured by **mystic transformation** (Xuanhua),
perhaps this is **Laozi**’s (the Old Master) true intent.

Therefore, the account is made.

In the **tenth year of the Great Virtue** (Dayan) season of **winter** (Dong),
on the **twelfth month** (Shiyue), the **full moon** (Wang) of the **twenty-fourth day** (Ershi),
**Shidi** (Disciple) **Juchang Ren** (任士林) of **Shu** (Shu),
wrote this in the **moneyed abode** (Qiantang) of the **Natural Daoists** (Ziran Daoshi).」

chunks.original_text: 玄经原旨发挥 经名：玄经原旨发挥。 元杜道坚撰。 二卷。 是书以《皇极 疏《老子》，凡十二章。 前有作者自序。 复有其弟子任士林序。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞神部玉诀类。 玄经原旨发挥序 老子自孔子称曰犹龙，庄周尊曰玄圣，历代尊行其教，上尊号者至矣。 窃观由商历周，九百余年，三度散关，四掌史职，着《道德玄经》二篇，橐钥天地玄同有无，实一天人之书。 道坚尝着《玄经原旨》，亦既脱稿，思昔观复谢高士所编实录年谱，纪载颇详，然引用年代尚多异同，久怀考正，未能也。 今采摭《皇极》元会运世，参订经旨，辑为十有二章，非敢有作，吾犹及史之阙文也。 夫孔子本鲁史，作《春秋》，始周平王。 邵氏本《连山》，着《皇极经世书》，自尧始。 愚之本《玄经》着《原旨》，复征古史为发挥，故不得不自先天始也。 此书之旨，不惟有极以来，已然之世代可征，而无极以前，未然之朕兆庸有可推。 后之有志古始者，当有考云。 大德十年中和后二日教门后学当涂杜道坚谨序。 玄经原旨发挥卷上 教门后学当涂杜道坚着 老圣着《玄经》，以道德名者，尊皇道，尚帝德也。 言道德则王伯功力在焉。 尝观康节以老子阐《皇极》，故愚以《皇极》疏老子，同一道也。 天下惟道理最大。 老子言道而不言理，理其在乎。 天地古今，君臣民物之间，各具理气象数，莫不由斯道也。 《皇极经世》所以系皇帝王伯道德功力，亦不出理气象数之四端。 老子日：域中有四大，道大，天大，地大，王亦大。 愚着《原旨发挥》 十有二章，前六章迷皇帝王伯道德功力之叔。 后六章迷老子降生，授经西游之略。 又岂能外理气象数而有言耶，皆所以明大道也。 言先天理：也，言元始气也，开物非象乎，数其在矣。 象数具而人道兴焉。 其始太上，其次三五，其次王伯。 喻以岁，则太上春也，三五夏也，王伯秋也，冬则闭物之后开物之前乎。 喻以日，则旦而昼，昼而暮。 喻以身，则幼而壮，壮而老也。 惟其会运有不同，故其世代有修短。 观者当自考之。 先天章一 先天，先天而天者也。 其虚无自然无极之道乎。 老子曰：无名天地之始，曰道生一，一生二，是皆形容先天之道，可以意会而不可以言象求也。 《易》曰：易有太极，是生两仪。 易，太易也，道也，无极也。 易有太极，道生一也。 一生二，太极生两仪也。 周子则曰：太极，本无极也。 《文言》曰：先天而天，弗违后天，而奉天时。 右先天之道。 论议不一，有先则必有后，有先后则必有中。 见诸典籍，大有三，以太极为中者，则极前为先天，极后为后天，此以道言也。 以伏羲之画为先天，文王之重为后天者，此以卦言也。 以一元中，分前六会为先天，后六会为复天，此以世言也。 凡天下事事物物，莫不各有一先天之道。 言先天则后天在焉。 以吾身而言，有一情未动之先，有有生未生之先。 以天地而言，则有天地未分之先，同一先天也。 先天者，其道乎，其存而不论者乎。 元始章二 元始，一元之始也。 老子曰：有物混成，先天地生。 曰：天下有始，以为天下母。 曰：能知古始，是谓道纪。 《易》曰：大哉乾元，万物资始。 乾元者，始而亨者也。 列子曰：天地之先，无物。

**Exposition on the Original Meaning of the Mysterious Classic**

**Title:** *Exposition on the Original Meaning of the Mysterious Classic*
**Author:** Du Daojian of the Yuan dynasty
**Volume:** Two
This work interprets the *Huangji* commentary on the *Laozi*, comprising twelve chapters. It includes a preface by the author and another by his disciple Ren Shilin.
**Source:** *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongshen* Section, *Jade Instructions* Category.

---

**Preface to *Exposition on the Original Meaning of the Mysterious Classic***

Since Confucius praised Laozi as "like a dragon" and Zhuang Zhou honored him as the "Mysterious Sage," successive dynasties have revered and practiced his teachings, bestowing upon him the highest titles. Observing the span from the Shang to the Zhou—over nine hundred years—Laozi thrice passed through the Hangu Pass, four times held the office of historian, and composed the *Mysterious Classic of the Dao and Its Virtue* in two scrolls. This work, like a bellows harmonizing Heaven and Earth, unifying being and non-being, is truly a book of the unity of Heaven and humanity.

I, Daojian, once composed *The Original Meaning of the Mysterious Classic*, which has since been completed. Reflecting on the *Veritable Records* compiled by the recluse Xie Gaoshi, I found its chronological records quite detailed, yet discrepancies in the cited eras remained. Though I long wished to verify and correct them, I was unable. Now, drawing from the *Supreme Principles of the Imperial Ultimate* and its cycles of cosmic transformation, I have collated and annotated the classic’s essential meaning into twelve chapters. I dare not claim originality; rather, I have filled in the lacunae of history.

Confucius, basing his work on the annals of Lu, composed the *Spring and Autumn Annals*, beginning with King Ping of Zhou. Master Shao, grounding his work in the *Lianshan*, wrote the *Supreme Principles Through the Ages*, starting with Yao. My own *Exposition on the Original Meaning*, rooted in the *Mysterious Classic*, likewise draws upon ancient history for its elaboration. Thus, it cannot but begin with the era before Heaven.

The purpose of this book is not only to verify the ages since the establishment of the Supreme Ultimate but also to infer the signs of what preceded the Ultimate of Non-being. Those who aspire to understand the origins of antiquity may find here material for reflection.

Respectfully inscribed by Du Daojian of Dangtu, a later student of the Teaching, on the second day after the Zhonghe festival in the tenth year of the Dade era.

---

**Exposition on the Original Meaning of the Mysterious Classic, Volume One**
**Author:** Du Daojian of Dangtu, a later student of the Teaching

The Sagely Laozi composed the *Mysterious Classic*, naming it after the Dao and its virtue to honor the imperial Dao and exalt the sovereign’s power. Where the Dao and virtue are spoken of, the merits of kings and hegemons are implicit.

I have observed that Master Kangjie (Shao Yong) elucidated the *Supreme Principles* through Laozi, so I, in turn, interpret Laozi through the *Supreme Principles*—both are of the same Dao. Nothing in the world surpasses the Dao and principle. Laozi spoke of the Dao but not of principle, yet principle is surely inherent within it. Between Heaven and Earth, past and present, among rulers, ministers, the people, and all things, each possesses its own principle, qi, image, and number, all deriving from this Dao.

The *Supreme Principles Through the Ages* traces the moral power and achievements of emperors, kings, and hegemons, yet it does not transcend the four aspects of principle, qi, image, and number. Laozi said: "Within the realm, there are four great things: the Dao is great, Heaven is great, Earth is great, and the king is also great." In my *Exposition* of twelve chapters, the first six elucidate the moral power and achievements of emperors, kings, and hegemons, while the latter six outline Laozi’s birth, transmission of the classic, and journey to the West. How could these discussions exist apart from principle, qi, image, and number? All serve to illuminate the great Dao.

To speak of the principle before Heaven is to speak of the primordial qi. Is not the opening of things an image? And is not number inherent within it? When image and number are complete, the human Dao arises. In the beginning was the Supreme (Taishang), followed by the Three and Five, then kings and hegemons. Metaphorically, the Supreme is spring, the Three and Five summer, kings and hegemons autumn, and winter lies between the closing of things and their reopening. As with the day: dawn, then noon, then dusk. As with the body: youth, then maturity, then old age. Only because the conjunction of cosmic cycles differs do the ages vary in duration. The reader must examine this for themselves.

---

**Chapter One: Before Heaven**

"Before Heaven" means that which precedes Heaven. Is it not the Dao of Non-being, of emptiness and spontaneity? Laozi said: "Nameless, it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth," and "The Dao gives birth to the One, the One gives birth to the Two." These all describe the Dao before Heaven, which can be grasped in the mind but not sought through words or images.

The *Book of Changes* says: "The Changes possess the Supreme Ultimate, which gives birth to the Two Modes." The *Changes* is the Great Change, the Dao, the Non-Ultimate. "The Changes possess the Supreme Ultimate" is the Dao giving birth to the One. "The One gives birth to the Two" is the Supreme Ultimate giving birth to the Two Modes. Master Zhou said: "The Supreme Ultimate is fundamentally the Non-Ultimate." The *Wenyan* states: "That which precedes Heaven is not opposed; that which follows Heaven accords with the seasons."

On the Dao before Heaven, discussions vary. Where there is a prior, there must be a posterior; where there is prior and posterior, there must be a middle. As seen in the classics, there are three major interpretations: those who take the Supreme Ultimate as the middle consider what precedes it as "before Heaven" and what follows as "after Heaven"—this speaks of the Dao. Those who take Fu Xi’s trigrams as "before Heaven" and King Wen’s hexagrams as "after Heaven" speak of the hexagrams. Those who divide the one cosmic cycle into the first six conjunctions as "before Heaven" and the latter six as "returning Heaven" speak of the ages.

All things in the world, without exception, possess their own Dao before Heaven. To speak of "before Heaven" is to imply "after Heaven." Regarding our own bodies, there is a state before emotions arise and a state before birth. Regarding Heaven and Earth, there is a state before their separation. All are "before Heaven." Is "before Heaven" not the Dao? Is it not that which exists yet is not discussed?

---

**Chapter Two: The Primordial Beginning**

"The Primordial Beginning" is the beginning of the one cosmic cycle. Laozi said: "There is a thing, formless yet complete, born before Heaven and Earth," and "The world has a beginning, which may be regarded as the mother of the world," and "To know the ancient beginning is called the thread of the Dao."

The *Book of Changes* says: "Great indeed is the primal power of Qian! All things owe their beginning to it." The primal power of Qian is that which begins and brings to fruition. Liezi said: "Before Heaven and Earth, there was nothing."

chunks.original_text: 无物，天地安从生。 曰：有太易，有太初，有太始，有太素。 天地之先，有五太。 列子言其四而不言太极，其曰气形质具，万物浑沦，而未相离。 言浑沦，则太极在焉。 必有神帝者主乎其间。 《易》所谓神也者，妙万物而为言，故主宰之谓帝，是曰元始。 国家严事祈天求命，必斋戒以将之，盖有所祖也。 尧曰：咨尔舜，天之历数在尔躬，允执其中。 故世之言天者，必假历数以明之。 诸家载籍不同，惟邵子《皇极经世》可法焉。 其原推本易老之言，参之《尧典》，钦若昊天，历象曰月星辰，验诸皇帝王伯道德功力，而成其书。 经以元会运世，讳以日月星辰，一元十二会，一会三十运，一运十二世，一世三十年，一年十二月，一月三十日，一日十二时，一时三十分，一分十二杪。 《易》与天地准，《皇极》又准於《易》，《易》虽不言历数，而曰极其数，遂定天下之象者，历数在矣。 《皇极》之用十二、三十者，其法以元准岁，会准月，运准日，世准时也。 一世三十年，一运十二世，三百六十年。 一会三十运，一万八百年。 一元十二会，一十二万九千六百年。 而天地万物，一元之数终焉。 元而上，杪而下，存而不论矣。 其要以会准月者十二，会应十二辰也。 天地之气，始於子，终於亥，其始一会应於子，二会应於丑，顺而十二会则终於亥矣。 终则有始，一元而一元，此道之所以始乎。 无始终乎无终，知此则可与造物者游，而始得乎环中。 元经会之一，始於太易。 太易日甲一月子一　星甲一辰子一太易，未见气也。 太易初年之岁、月、日、时，俱起甲子。 历五千四百年而有太初。 太初日甲一月子一　星己十六辰子一百八十一太初，元气始萌也。 又如其年，合一万八百年是为一会。 大则当一岁之子月，小则当一日之子时，先天无极，元始祖气，至此而静极者动，一阳生焉。 康节有云：冬至子之半，天心无改移，一阳初动处，万物未生时。 盖此谓也。 元经会之二，有太始。 太始日甲一月丑二　星甲三十一辰子三百六十一太始，气形始端也。 五千四百年，而有太素。 太素日甲一月丑二　星己四十六辰子五百四十一太素，形变有质也。 又如其年，合二万一千六百年为二会，应一岁之丑月，一日之丑时，惚恍之物象，窈冥之真精者，玄同妙合，二阳生矣。 元经会之三，有太极。 太极日甲一月寅三　星甲六十一辰子七百二十一太极，万物混沦而未相离也。 所谓存於挥沌未判之先，达於气质，成象之表，充塞天地，贯通古今，大造不能外者也。 五千四百年，浑沦肇判，阴阳开辟，应一岁之寅月，朔后之半月，一日之寅时，寅初之四刻者，乾坤成象，以清以宁，三阳泰而万物动萌矣。 右一元之始，历五太，凡二会，有半积，二万七千年。 邵子称日甲月子於元之始。 愚於五太称年者，以其有理气象数，具於未然之中也。 殆亦画前之易欤。 老子曰：天下万物生於有，有生於无。 《皇极》数起于天地未开辟，二会半之先。 数终于天地已闭物，一会半之后。 亥子丑三会，犹岁之冬日之夜。 谓有物邪，则天地玄冥，万物伏藏。 谓无物邪，则窈冥恍惚，万物未尝不在。 故曰：先天地而始，后天地而终，终则又变而通矣。

**Chapter Two: The Primordial Beginning (continued)**

Before there was anything, how could Heaven and Earth arise? It is said: There is *Taiyi* (Grand Simplicity), *Taichu* (Grand Inception), *Taishi* (Grand Commencement), and *Taisu* (Grand Simplicity of Form). Before Heaven and Earth, there are the Five Grand States. Liezi speaks of four but omits *Taiji* (Grand Ultimate). He states: "Qi, form, and substance are all present, yet the myriad things remain undifferentiated, not yet separated." Where there is undifferentiation, *Taiji* is already therein. There must be a divine sovereign presiding over this state. The *Book of Changes* speaks of the divine as that which "subtly brings forth the myriad things"—thus, the sovereign is called *Di* (Emperor), and this is termed the *Yuanshi* (Primordial Beginning). When the state performs solemn rites to pray to Heaven and seek its mandate, it must do so with fasting and purification, for there is an origin to which it traces. Yao said: "Ah, you, Shun! The celestial reckoning now rests upon you; hold fast to the center." Thus, those who speak of Heaven must borrow the reckoning of time to make it clear. The records of various schools differ, but only Shao Yong’s *Huangji Jingshi* (Supreme Principles Governing the World) can be taken as a model. Its origins trace back to the words of the *Book of Changes* and Laozi, corroborated by the *Canon of Yao*, revering the vast Heaven, observing the celestial bodies of sun, moon, and stars, and verified through the moral power and achievements of emperors, kings, and sages—thus was the book completed.

The *Huangji Jingshi* reckons time by *yuan* (cosmic cycles), *hui* (conjunctions), *yun* (epochs), and *shi* (generations). Its symbols are the sun, moon, and stars. One *yuan* consists of twelve *hui*; one *hui* of thirty *yun*; one *yun* of twelve *shi*; one *shi* of thirty years; one year of twelve months; one month of thirty days; one day of twelve hours; one hour of thirty *fen*; and one *fen* of twelve *miao*. The *Book of Changes* accords with Heaven and Earth, and the *Huangji Jingshi* accords with the *Book of Changes*. Though the *Book of Changes* does not speak of the reckoning of time, it says: "Exhaust its numbers, and the images of the world are thereby determined"—thus, the reckoning of time is implicit. The *Huangji Jingshi* uses twelve and thirty in its method: one *yuan* corresponds to a year, one *hui* to a month, one *yun* to a day, and one *shi* to an hour. One *shi* is thirty years; one *yun* is twelve *shi*, totaling 360 years. One *hui* is thirty *yun*, totaling 10,800 years. One *yuan* is twelve *hui*, totaling 129,600 years. Thus, the reckoning of one *yuan* encompasses Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. Beyond the *yuan* lies the *miao*; below the *miao*, there is only that which exists yet is not discussed. Its essential principle is that one *hui* corresponds to a month, and twelve *hui* align with the twelve earthly branches. The qi of Heaven and Earth begins at *zi* and ends at *hai*; the first *hui* corresponds to *zi*, the second to *chou*, and so on through the twelve *hui*, concluding at *hai*. When the end is reached, a new beginning arises—one *yuan* follows another. This is how the Dao begins. Without beginning or end, it is endless. Knowing this, one may wander with the Creator and first attain the center of the circle.

The first *hui* of the *yuan* begins with *Taiyi*:
- *Taiyi*: Day *jia* 1, Month *zi* 1, Star *jia* 1, Earthly Branch *zi* 1—*Taiyi* is the state before qi appears.
The initial year, month, day, and hour of *Taiyi* all commence with *jiazi*. After 5,400 years, *Taichu* arises:
- *Taichu*: Day *jia* 1, Month *zi* 1, Star *ji* 16, Earthly Branch *zi* 181—*Taichu* is when primordial qi first stirs.
Another 5,400 years complete one *hui*, totaling 10,800 years. In the grand scale, this corresponds to the *zi* month of a year; in the small scale, to the *zi* hour of a day. Before Heaven, in the state of *Wuji* (Ultimate Non-being), the ancestral qi of the Primordial Beginning reaches its utmost stillness and begins to move—one *yang* is born. As Kangjie said: "At the midpoint of the *zi* hour of the winter solstice, the heart of Heaven remains unchanged. Where the first *yang* stirs, the myriad things are yet unborn." This is what he meant.

The second *hui* of the *yuan* brings *Taishi*:
- *Taishi*: Day *jia* 1, Month *chou* 2, Star *jia* 31, Earthly Branch *zi* 361—*Taishi* is when qi and form first take shape.
After 5,400 years, *Taisu* arises:
- *Taisu*: Day *jia* 1, Month *chou* 2, Star *ji* 46, Earthly Branch *zi* 541—*Taisu* is when form transforms and substance emerges.
Another 10,800 years complete the second *hui*, totaling 21,600 years, corresponding to the *chou* month of a year and the *chou* hour of a day. In this state of indistinct images and profound essence, the mysterious and the wondrous merge—two *yang* are born.

The third *hui* of the *yuan* brings *Taiji*:
- *Taiji*: Day *jia* 1, Month *yin* 3, Star *jia* 61, Earthly Branch *zi* 721—*Taiji* is when the myriad things are undifferentiated and not yet separated.
This is what is meant by existing before the chaos was divided, extending beyond qi and form to the realm of images, filling Heaven and Earth, and spanning past and present—something even the great Creator cannot transcend. After 5,400 years, the undifferentiated begins to separate, and the division of *yin* and *yang* commences, corresponding to the *yin* month of a year, the half-month after the new moon, the *yin* hour of a day, and the first four *ke* of the *yin* hour. Here, the images of *Qian* and *Kun* take form, pure and tranquil—three *yang* harmonize, and the myriad things stir and sprout.

The beginning of one *yuan* passes through the Five Grand States, spanning two and a half *hui*, totaling 27,000 years. Shao Yong designated the day as *jia* and the month as *zi* at the beginning of the *yuan*. In my humble opinion, the Five Grand States are reckoned by years because their principles, qi, images, and numbers are already present in the state of "not yet." This is perhaps the *Yi* before the first line is drawn. Laozi said: "The myriad things under Heaven are born of being; being is born of non-being." The reckoning of the *Huangji Jingshi* begins before Heaven and Earth were opened, prior to two and a half *hui*. It concludes after Heaven and Earth have closed, following one and a half *hui*. The three *hui* of *hai*, *zi*, and *chou* are like winter in a year and night in a day. If one says there are things, then Heaven and Earth are dark and obscure, and the myriad things lie hidden. If one says there are no things, then in the profound and indistinct, the myriad things are never absent. Thus, it is said: "It begins before Heaven and Earth and ends after them; when it ends, it transforms and flows anew."
