chunks.original_text: 春台如登春台。 若冬豫兮若冬涉川。 凶年大军之后，必有凶年。 终朝飘风不终朝。 终日骤雨不终日。 终日号而嗌不嗄。 日益为学日益。 日损为道日损。 日久民之迷其日固久。 阴阳负阴抱阳。 寒热躁胜寒，静胜热。 草木 草木万物草木之生也柔脆，其死也枯槁。 抱木合抱之木，生於毫末。 木共木强则共。 刑棘荆棘生焉。 根柢深根固柢。 归根夫物芸芸，各归其根。 轻根重为轻根。 宫室 九层台九层之台，起於垒土。 朝甚除朝甚除，仓甚虚。 仓虚见上。 户牖凿户牖以为室。 凿室见上。 塞兑塞其兑，闭其门。 闭门塞其兑，闭其门。 开兑开其兑，济其事。 出户不出户知天下。 窥牖不窥牖，见天道。 方隅大方无隅。 安居安其居，乐其俗。 乐俗安其居，乐其俗。 狭居无狭其所居。 关键善闭，无关键而不可开。 春台如登春台。 四邻犹兮若畏四邻。 荣观虽有荣观，燕处超然。 妙门众妙之门。 有室有室之用。 玄门玄牝之门。 天门天门开阖。 器用 朴器朴散则为器。 神器天下神器，不敢为也。 大器大器晚成。 利器国之利器，不可以示人。 民多利器，国家滋昏。 兵器夫佳兵者，不祥之器。 埏埴埏埴以为器。 器用有器之用，非君子之器，不得已而用之。 什伯器使有什伯之器而不用。 橐钥天地之间、其犹橐钥乎。 刍狗以万物为刍狗。 以百姓为刍狗。 金玉金玉满堂，莫之能守。 车用当其无有车之用。 如玉不欲碌碌如玉。 怀玉被褐怀玉。 辐毂三＋辐共一毂。 拱璧虽有拱璧，以先驷马。 无舆数舆无舆。 舟舆虽有舟舆，无所乘之。 辎重君子终日行不离辎重。 匠斲是谓代大匠斲。 左契圣人执左契，而不责於人。 司契有德司契，无德司彻。 筹策善计不用筹策。 利剑带利剑。 张弓天之道，其犹张弓乎。 天网天纲恢恢，疏而不失。 结绳使民复结绳而用之。 绳约善结者； 无绳约而不可解。 服饰 服采服文采。 美服甘其食，美其服。 被褐被褐怀玉。 食货 饮食厌饮食。 余食余食赘行。 甘食甘其食。 食税以其上食税之多。 乐饵乐与饵，过客止。 财货财货有余。 贵货不贵难得之货。 难得之货，令人行妨。 欲不欲，不贵难得之货。 禽虫 兕角兕无所投其角。 虎爪虎无所措其爪。 驷马虽有拱璧，以先驷马。 走马却走马以粪。 戎马戎马生於郊。 毒虫毒虫不螫。 猛兽猛兽不据。 攫鸟攫鸟不搏。 太牢众人熙熙，如享太 牢。 渊鱼渊不可脱於鱼。 小鲜治大国若烹小鲜。 迭字 绳绳绳绳兮不可名。 芸芸夫物芸芸，复归其根。 熙熙众人熙熙。 乘乘乘乘兮若无所归。 沌沌沌沌兮，俗人昭昭，我独若昏。 昭昭见上。 察察俗人察察，我独闷闷。 闷闷其政闷问，其民淳淳。 淳淳见上。 碌碌不欲碌碌如玉，落落如石。 落落见上。 缺缺其民缺缺。 玄经原旨发挥卷下竟 玄经原旨发挥序 上古之初，人人老子，家家道德，言之不可闻，安有五千言以为之经。 大朴既散元经会之七，有圣人跨历商周，笑视争夺，遐想庸成大庭之不可复，於是出五千言以陈古义以正人心。 青牛去远微言转堙，五千演为数十万言，将以发道德之所未尽，使博大。 真人与上三皇同时，必不着书，使后世尽汉文，尽盖公。 则原旨之书，亦不出於今之河上。 此书自先天而来，十有二章，别自为书，开阖古今，经纬理数，得函关之的意，集玄学之大成。
chunks.translated_text:
**Spring Platform**
Like ascending the Spring Platform.
Cautious as winter, like winter crossing rivers.

**Years of calamity**—after great armies, there will surely be years of calamity.
Morning gusts do not last the morning.
Sudden rains of a day do not last the day.
All day’s wailing does not leave the throat hoarse.
**Learning daily**—daily learning, daily gain.
**Dao daily**—daily loss, daily Dao.
**Time’s delusion**—the longer people are deluded, the more fixed their delusion grows.

**Yin and Yang**
Yin embraces Yang, Yang embraces Yin.
Cold conquers heat, stillness conquers agitation.

**Grasses and Trees**
Grasses and trees—all things grow soft and tender, yet die withered and brittle.
A tree of embracing girth begins as a hair’s end.
Trees that lean together grow strong together.
Thorns and brambles spring from the same root.
**Deep roots**—deep roots, firm foundations.
**Returning to root**—all things, myriad and varied, return to their roots.
**Light roots**—heavy burdens make for light roots.

**Dwellings**
Nine-layered platforms rise from piled earth.
Morning’s labor, morning’s rest; granaries empty, the ruler is seen.
Windows pierced—when dwellings are pierced, the ruler is revealed.
Seal the openings, close the doors.
Close the doors, seal the openings.
Open the openings, accomplish the task.
**Beyond the door**—without leaving the door, one knows the world.
**Peering through windows**—without peering, one sees the Dao’s way.
**The Great Square**—the Great Square has no corners.
**Contentment**—settle where you dwell, delight in your customs.
Delight in your customs, settle where you dwell.
**Narrow dwellings**—though dwellings be narrow, do not narrow your place.
**Gates and keys**—good gates close well; without a key, they cannot be opened.
Like ascending the Spring Platform.
**Neighbors**—fearful as if fearing four neighbors.
**Grand observatories**—though grand observatories exist, dwell in transcendence.

**Mystic Gates**
The Gate of Wonders—gate of all wonders.
**Dwelling’s use**—the use of dwelling.
The Mystic Gate—the gate of the Mystic Female.
The Heavenly Gate—opening and closing of Heaven’s gate.

**Implements**
**Rude tools**—crude tools scattered become implements.
**Divine tools**—the world’s divine tools, dare not be used.
**Great tools**—great tools take long to mature.
**Sharp tools**—a state’s sharp tools should not be displayed.
Many sharp tools, the state grows dim.
**Weapons**—fine weapons are inauspicious tools.
**Clay molds**—molded clay becomes implements.
**Tool’s use**—implements have their uses; what is not the gentleman’s tool is used only when necessary.
**Ten and hundred tools**—though ten and hundred tools exist, they are not used.
**Pouch and key**—between Heaven and Earth, is it not like a pouch and key?
**Straw dogs**—all things as straw dogs.
People as straw dogs.
**Jade and gold**—gold and jade fill the hall, yet none can guard them.
**Chariots’ use**—when there is no chariot, chariots are useful.
Like jade, do not be clattering like jade.
**Clad in coarse cloth, holding jade**—clad in coarse cloth, holding jade.
**Spokes and hub**—three spokes meet at one hub.
**Bowed jade**—though bowed jade exists, prefer four-horse teams.
**No chariots**—without chariots, chariots are useless.
**Boats and chariots**—though boats and chariots exist, there is nothing to ride upon.
**Baggage**—the gentleman travels all day without leaving his baggage.
**Carpenters’ adze**—this is called replacing the master carpenter with an adze.
**Left contracts**—the sage holds the left contract but does not demand it of others.
**Contract keepers**—those with virtue keep contracts; those without, enforce them.
**Calculations**—good planners do not use calculations.
**Sharp swords**—wearing sharp swords.
**Drawing the bow**—Heaven’s way, is it not like drawing the bow?
**Heaven’s net**—Heaven’s vast net, wide yet nothing slips through.
**Knots**—make the people tie knots again.
**Ropes**—good knots are tied; without ropes, they cannot be undone.

**Attire**
**Decorative robes**—garments of embroidered patterns.
**Fine clothing**—delight in food, adorn in clothing.
**Clad in coarse cloth**—clad in coarse cloth, holding jade.

**Food and Wealth**
**Feasting**—feasting on food, gluttony.
**Excess food**—excess food, superfluous actions.
**Sweet food**—delight in food.
**Food taxes**—taxes on food, the more the upper classes tax.
**Delights and bait**—delight and bait, travelers stop.
**Wealth**—wealth in abundance.
**Precious goods**—do not prize difficult-to-obtain goods.
Difficult-to-obtain goods cause obstruction.
**Desire not**—do not desire what is difficult to obtain.

**Beasts and Creatures**
**Rhinoceros horns**—rhinoceroses have no place to cast their horns.
**Tiger claws**—tigers have no place to place their claws.
**Four-horse teams**—though bowed jade exists, prefer four-horse teams.
**Galloping horses**—drive galloping horses with dung.
**Warhorses**—warhorses are born in the wilds.
**Poisonous insects**—poisonous insects do not sting.
**Fierce beasts**—fierce beasts do not seize.
**Snatching birds**—snatching birds do not clutch.
**Grand sacrifices**—people rejoice as if feasting on grand sacrifices.
**Deep fish**—fish cannot escape the deep.
**Small fish**—governing a great state like poaching small fish.

**Repeated Characters**
**Ropes**—ropes, ropes, beyond naming.
**Myriad things**—myriad things, return to their roots.
**Rejoicing**—people rejoice.
**Buoyant**—buoyant, as if nowhere to return.
**Muddled**—muddled, muddled; common folk are bright, I alone seem dim.
**Bright**—bright, as above.
**Keen**—common folk are keen, I alone am confused.
**Confused governance**—confused governance, questions arise; its people are pure.
**Pure**—pure, as above.
**Clattering**—do not clatter like jade, steadfast like stone.
**Steadfast**—steadfast, as above.
**Deficient**—its people are deficient.

**The Original Doctrine’s Essence**
The Original Doctrine’s Essence—its unfolding, Volume Below Complete.
The Original Doctrine’s Essence—its unfolding, Preface.

In the beginning of antiquity, everyone was Laozi, every home held virtue and Dao.
Words could not be heard—how could there be five thousand words as scripture?

The Great Uncarved Block scattered; the Original Scripture gathered the seven.
A sage traversed Shang and Zhou, laughing at strife and contention, imagining the Great Court’s irrecoverable loss.
Thus, he spoke five thousand words to expound ancient principles and rectify the mind.

The Blue Ox departed far; subtle words were buried, five thousand words expanded into tens of thousands.
To exhaust the Dao’s virtue, making it vast.

The True Person coexisted with the Three Sovereigns—
Surely he did not write books, lest later ages exhaust Hanwen and Gai Gong.
Thus, the Original Doctrine’s book also does not emerge from today’s Riverbank.

This book, from before Heaven, has twelve chapters, standing alone as a text.
Opening and closing ancient and modern, weaving logic and numbers,
Grasping the Gate’s intent, gathering the Great Achievement of Mystic Learning.

chunks.original_text: 读之者轩轩乎见鸿蒙，泠泠然适建德，身世自远，内外俱忘，亦犹渊明之羲皇，上禅宗之威音。 前周茂叔之太极本无极，虽然运有污隆，而古今无二。 道术有分裂，而宇宙无两身，安知老子之非先生，又安知先生之非我。 异时白石洞天水光山色之中，从杖履而稽首三，问者必属之我矣。 卢山道士黄石翁敬书。 生民果有初乎。 夫开物成务，十三卦之外无余闻，而云火水龙鸟师之纪，郯子之学为有征。 是故庄周之论容成而下，凡十二氏，夫岂寓言。 黄帝以前封泰山者七十二，又岂臆说与？ 盖五太肇而化育参，九纪终而甲历作，推之而可求其故，迦之而可见其倪者，《易》《老》而外，惟《皇极》一书而已。 然尝论之，元会运世大年也，岁月日时小年也。 皇帝王伯之所由分，开物闭物之所由遂，其可究者。 日甲月巳星癸，为少昊之世，而甲子纪年。 日甲月午星甲，为夏禹之日，而王道始着。 然则六万四千八百有一年以往之故，断自尧。 甲辰而上，岂无可载之事，特简策散落，举之而无其征，此尧夫所由略也。 南谷杜尊师，道际两朝，学探古始，尝以谓一身之八卦，为盘古开天之征，一日之旦夜，为开物闭物之辨。 故摭诸古史历书所称九纪，参之老子微意，迄禹二会半以前，逆推而分初中后三皇氏，以系人极既立之事。 由是而求之，则於《皇极》书为有原始之补，而其意则尊皇道、尚帝德而已也。 题其书曰《原旨发挥》，分为十二章。 上六章至周而终，下六章述老子本末。 大抵发明老子身为藏史，凡三皇五帝之书，无不目见，所着五千言，辞玄旨邃，隐然无名古史，故取之以补邵子之所不陈，殆人间宜有书也。 尊师老子徒也，谓言涉天人不可也，然使为国家者，得其言而用之，则君俞於上，臣敏於下，斯民囿玄穆之化，或者老子意乎。 於是乎叙。 大德十年冬十有二月望，弟子句章任士林，书于钱塘自然道士之斋。

「He who reads this text shall stand in awe of the **Hongmeng** (the primal chaos of creation), and find himself naturally attuned to the **Jiande** (the Virtue of the Lord on High).
The past and present fade away, the self and the world are both forgotten—
just as **Yuanming** (Xian Zhi) ascended to **Xihuang** (the Dao of the Primordial Sovereign),
or sought the **Weiyin** (the awe-inspiring resonance) of the **Chanzong** (Zen Patriarchs).

The **Taiji** (Great Polarity) of **Mao Shou** (Master Mao of the Zhou) was originally **Wuji** (Non-Polarity).
Though it unfolded with **wuyun** (flourish and decline), the ancient and modern remain undivided.

The **Dao** (Way) and its arts may diverge,
yet the **universe** (Tianren) has but one body—
how can one know that **Laozi** (the Old Master) was not **Zisheng** (the First Sage)?
And how can one know that **Zisheng** (the First Sage) was not **I**?

In the midst of **Bai Shidongtian** (White Stone Cave’s celestial realm),
where water gleams and mountains rise,
I take up my staff and bow three times,
for those who inquire shall surely trace it back to me.

The **Lu Mountain Daoist, Huang Shigong** (Master Huang of Yellow Stone) respectfully dedicates this book.

Did the people truly have a beginning?

To open things and complete undertakings,
beyond the **thirteen gua** (trigrams) there is no further account,
yet the records of **Yunhuo** (Cloud Fire), **Shuili** (Water and Land), **Long** (Dragon), and **Niao Shi** (Bird Master)
and **Zishouzi** (Master Zhi of the Chen) bear witness to its truth.

Thus, **Zhuang Zhou**’s discourse on **Rongcheng** (Nourishing Perfection) and the twelve **Shi** (Sages),
was it not a **yuyan** (allegorical tale)?

Before **Huangdi** (the Yellow Emperor), there were seven **Tai** (Great) who ascended Mount Tai—
were they not **yicuo** (imagined conjecture)?

The **Five Sovereigns** (Wutai) initiated change,
and **three transformations** (San San) took root.
When the **Nine Ages** (Jiuzhi) concluded, the **Jia calendar** (Jia calendar system) emerged—
one can trace its origin,
and glimpse its subtle traces—
only in the **Book of Huangji** (the *Huangjing*) and the **Laozi** (the *Laozi*) does this remain.

Yet when I ponder it,
the **Yuanhui** (Great Cycle), **Yunshi** (Evolution of the World), and **Dayan** (Great Year) are vast,
while **years, months, days, and times** are minute.

The division of **Huangdi** (the Yellow Emperor) and **Wangbo** (the August Sovereign),
the fulfillment of opening and closing things—
its essence can be examined.

**Dayi** (Day of Jia), **Monthi** (Month of Yi), **Xinggui** (Star of Gui),
mark the age of **Shaohao** (Minor Hao),
and the **Jiazi** (Jia-Zi) calendar begins.

**Dayi** (Day of Jia), **Monthwu** (Month of Wu), **Xingjia** (Star of Jia),
signify the day of **Xia Yu** (Great Yu of Xia),
and the **Wangdao** (Way of the Kings) takes form.

Yet then, from the **6480 years** hence,
the reckoning breaks at **Yao** (Emperor Yao).

From **Jiachen** (Jia-Chen) onward—
were there no events worthy of record?
It is merely that **strategies and documents** (jiance) were lost and scattered,
and though raised, they lack confirming evidence—
this is why **Yao**’s deeds were omitted.

**Du Zunsheng** (Master Du of the Southern Valley),
a **Daoist** (Dao) spanning two dynasties,
his learning delving into ancient origins,
once declared that the **eight gua of one’s person** (Yibing Ba Gua),
were the signs of **Pangu opening Heaven** (Pangu’s creation of the cosmos),
and the **dawn and night of a day** (Dan-Ye),
the distinction between opening and closing things.

Thus, I gathered the **Nine Ages** (Jiuzhi) from ancient histories and calendars,
and cross-referenced them with **Laozi**’s subtle meanings,
to trace back to the **first, middle, and latter Three Sovereigns** (Sanhuang San San),
and connect them to the **established human extreme** (Renji) of **Huangdi** (the Yellow Emperor).

By this method, one can find
the **original intent** (Yuanshi) of the *Huangjing* (Book of Huangji),
and its purpose is to **revere the Sovereign’s Dao** (Huangdao) and **praise the Emperor’s virtue** (Dide).

I titled this book *Expounding the Original Intent* (Yuanshi Faxi),
divided into twelve chapters.

The first six chapters conclude with the **Zhou** (Zhou Dynasty),
the latter six expound on **Laozi**’s (the Old Master) beginning and end.

In essence, it reveals that **Laozi**’s (the Old Master) person was **Cangshi** (Hidden Historian),
his **five thousand words** (Wuyan) encompassing all the books of the **Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors** (Sanhuang Wudi),
with **profound words** (Xian) and **deep intent** (Suishi),
a **Cangshi** (Hidden Historian) without name in antiquity—
thus I took them to supplement **Shaozi** (Master Shao’s) unexpressed accounts,
and perhaps this is the book that humanity ought to have.

A disciple of **Laozi** (the Old Master), I say:
Words that touch upon **Heaven and Man** (Tianren) are beyond reach,
yet if rulers of states grasp his teachings and apply them,
then the **sovereign** (Jun) shall be **youshu** (auspicious and harmonious) above,
and the **ministers** (Chen) shall be **minxing** (responsive and sensitive) below—
thus the people shall be nurtured by **mystic transformation** (Xuanhua),
perhaps this is **Laozi**’s (the Old Master) true intent.

Therefore, the account is made.

In the **tenth year of the Great Virtue** (Dayan) season of **winter** (Dong),
on the **twelfth month** (Shiyue), the **full moon** (Wang) of the **twenty-fourth day** (Ershi),
**Shidi** (Disciple) **Juchang Ren** (任士林) of **Shu** (Shu),
wrote this in the **moneyed abode** (Qiantang) of the **Natural Daoists** (Ziran Daoshi).」
